qas.question: When did writers for Sounds first mention "post punk"?

plausible_answers.text: Siouxsie and the Banshees and Wire

qas.question: Who used sounds and lyrics similar to their contemporaries in 1977?

plausible_answers.text: as exploring "harsh urban scrapings [,] controlled white noise" and "massively accented drumming".

qas.question: Which British acts never experimented with sounds?
What was seen as one of the least successful punk bands?

context: In <a0_0><b14_0>late 1977<b14_0/><a0_0/>, music writers for Sounds first used the terms <b10_0>"New Musick" and "post punk"<b10_0/> to describe British acts such as <a5_0><b11_0><b17_0>Siouxsie and <a4_0>the Banshees<a4_0/> and Wire<b17_0/><b11_0/><a5_0/>, who began <a1_0>experimenting<a1_0/> with sounds, lyrics and aesthetics that differed significantly from their punk contemporaries. <a2_0><b15_0>Writer<b15_0/><a2_0/> <a6_0>Jon Savage<a6_0/> described some of these early developments <b12_0>as exploring "harsh urban scrapings [,] controlled white noise" and "massively accented drumming".<b12_0/> In <a3_0><b16_0>January <a9_0><b13_0>1978<b16_0/><a9_0/><a3_0/>,<b13_0/> singer <a8_0>John Lydon<a8_0/> (then known as Johnny Rotten) announced the break-up of his pioneering punk band the <a7_0><b18_0>Sex Pistols<b18_0/><a7_0/>, citing his disillusionment with punk's musical predictability and cooption by commercial interests, as well as his desire to explore more diverse interests.
